question.text: At a point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> on the earth’s surface the angle of dip, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>δ</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. At a point <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> on the earth’s surface, the angle of dip, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>δ</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. We can interpret that:

options.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> are both located in the northern hemisphere.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> is located in the southern hemisphere and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> is located in the northern hemisphere.

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> is located in the northern hemisphere and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> is located in the southern hemisphere.
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>B</mi></math> are both located in the southern hemisphere.

solution.text:
As we know that the angle of dip is the angle between earth's resultant magnetic field from horizontal.

At the equator, dip is zero. At Northern Hemisphere, dip is positive. At Southern Hemisphere, dip is negative.

Since, the field lines originate from the South Pole, the angle of dip is negative in Southern Hemisphere. Similarly, as the field lines terminate at the North Pole, the angle of dip is positive in Northern Hemisphere.
